item.title: Taylor's series and Maclaurin's series
item.author: poincaregyp@gmail.com (Aditya Kumar Singh)
item.description:
Motivation

Given a continuous function $f(x)$. Can we find other $g(x)$ which is approximately same to $f(x)$ ?

Why do we want to do this ?

  • Sometime it is easier to deal with function like polynomial than to deal with complicated function like $sin(x) + cos(x)$.

  • Curiosity, why not ?

Taylor’s formula and Maclaurin’s formula

Let suppose $p(x)$ is a polynomial of degree $n$.

Maclaurin’s formula

Expanding function $p(x)$ as power of $x$ as

$$ \begin{equation} p(x) = c_{0} + c_{1}x + c_{2}x^{2}+\cdots+c_{n}x^{n} \end{equation} $$ differentiating it successfully $n$ times, we get

$$ % \begin{equation} p’(x) = c_{1}+2 \cdot c_{2}x+\cdots+n \cdot c_{n}x^{(n+1)} $$ $$ p’’(x) = 2 \cdot c_{2}+ 2 \cdot 3 \cdot c_{3}x +\cdots+ (n - 1) \cdot n \cdot c_{n}x^{(n+2)} $$ $$ \vdots $$ $$ p^{(n)}(x) = 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdots n \cdot c_{n} $$

setting $x = 0$ in above equations, we get $$ c_{0}= p(0), \quad c_{1} = \frac{p’(0)}{1!}, \quad c_{2} = \frac{p’’(0)}{2!}, \quad \cdots \quad c_{n} = \frac{p^{(n)}(0)}{n!} $$ putting these calculated coefficient in equation $1$, we get $$ \begin{equation} p(x) = p(0) + \frac{p’(0)}{1!}x + \frac{p’’(0)}{2!}x^{2} + \frac{p’’’(0)}{3!}x^{3} + \cdots + \frac{p^{(n)}(0)}{n!}x^{n} \end{equation} $$

Equation $2$ is called Maclaurin’s formula.

Till this point, we have not achieved anything beside finding coefficient value of $p(x)$.

Taylor’s formula

In Maclaurin’s formula, we are expanding function $p(x)$ as power of $x$, But we can also expand the equation with respect to power of $x - a$ where $a$ is a constant value.

$$ \begin{equation} p(x) = c_{0} + c_{1}(x - a) + c_{2}(x - a)^{2}+\cdots+c_{n}(x - a)^{n} \end{equation} $$

Lets apply same logic we applied to last section.

Differentiating it successfully $n$ times, we get

$$ p’(x) = c_{1}+2 \cdot c_{2}(x - a)+\cdots+n \cdot c_{n}(x - a)^{(n+1)} $$

$$ p’’(x) = 2 \cdot c_{2}+ 2 \cdot 3 \cdot c_{3}(x - a) +\cdots+ (n - 1) \cdot n \cdot c_{n}(x - a)^{(n+2)} $$

$$ \vdots $$

$$ p^{(n)}(x) = 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdots n \cdot c_{n} $$

setting $x = a$ in above equations, we get

$$ c_{0}= p(a), \quad c_{1} = \frac{p’(a)}{1!}, \quad c_{2} = \frac{p’’(a)}{2!}, \quad \cdots \quad c_{n} = \frac{p^{(n)}(a)}{n!} $$

putting these calculated coefficient in equation $3$, we get

$$ \begin{equation} p(x) = p(a) + \frac{p’(a)}{1!}(x - a) + \frac{p’’(a)}{2!}(x - a)^{2} + \frac{p’’’(a)}{3!}(x - a)^{3} + \cdots + \frac{p^{(n)}(a)}{n!}(x - a)^{n} \end{equation} $$

Equation $4$ is called Taylor’s formula.

Example

Let $p(x) = (4x + 3)^3$. $p(x)$ have derivative upto till degree 3.(higher derivative than 3 degree exists but is meaingless to this example, why ?)

$$ p’(x) = 12 (4x + 3)^2 $$

$$ p’’(x) = 96 (4x + 3) $$

$$ p’’’(x) = 386 $$

At $x = 0$, we have

$$ p(0) = 27, \qquad p’(0) = 108, \qquad p’’(0) = 288, \qquad p’’’(0) = 386 $$

Using Maclaurin’s formula(equation $2$), we have

$$ p(x) = 64x^3 + 144x^2 + 108x + 27 $$

At $x = 1$, we have $$ p(1) = 343, \qquad p’(1) = 588, \qquad p’’(1) = 672, \qquad p’’’(1) = 386 $$

Using Taylor’s formula(equation $4$), we have

$$ p(x) = 64(x - 1)^3 + 336(x -1)^2 + 588(x - 1) + 343 $$

Even though Taylor’s formula and Maclaurin’s formula looks different for $p(x)$, Both are same thing. It is just different way to represent $p(x)$.

Postulate

In last section, We were toying with different representation of polynomial $p(x)$.
